lessons.title: Filtering by patterns
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use conditions to select items where a property follows a pattern, like writers with a first_name starting with a.

Make sure to pick WHERE, followed by first_name LIKE 'a%'.

lessons.title: The LIKE keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use the LIKE keyword to check if values in a column like first_name follow a pattern.

Make sure to type LIKE.

lessons.title: Only with text values
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can only use LIKE conditions with text values, like those in the first_name column.

Make sure to type first_name.

lessons.title: Pattern
lessons.interactiveContent:
We call the text after the LIKE keyword a pattern, like 'a%' here.

Make sure to pick LIKE, followed by 'a%'.

lessons.title: A pattern is a text
lessons.interactiveContent:
A pattern is a piece of text we want the values in a column to match, so we also write patterns between single quotes, like 'a%'.

Make sure to pick ', followed by a%, and finally '.

lessons.title: Question: The LIKE keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which keyword do we use when we filter by a pattern?

LIKEBETWEEN

Make sure to pick LIKE.

lessons.title: Question: Only with text values
lessons.interactiveContent:
What type of values can we use LIKE with?

Only text valuesNumerical or text values

Only text values.

lessons.title: Question: Pattern
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do we call the text 'c%' that comes after LIKE?

A patternA keyword

A pattern.

lessons.title: Question: A pattern is a text
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we write patterns?

Between single quotes, like 'a%'Without quotes, like a%

Between single quotes, like 'a%'.

lessons.title: Example: The LIKE keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code LIKE to complete this query that selects items with an aroma starting with the letter c.

Make sure to type LIKE.

lessons.title: Example: Pattern
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the pattern 'chocolate%' to get the items that have an aroma starting with chocolate.

Make sure to type 'chocolate%'.

lessons.title: Example: A pattern is a text
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a pattern to filter for elements with an aroma starting with c.

Make sure to pick 'c%'.

lessons.title: No wildcard
lessons.interactiveContent:
With a pattern like 'a' we only match the item A, Milne, since 'A' is the only first_name with no letters beside 'a'.

Make sure to pick first_name, followed by LIKE, and finally 'a'.

lessons.title: The % symbol
lessons.interactiveContent:
To find values that start with a text like 'a', followed by any other text, we use the symbol %.

Make sure to type %.

lessons.title: The % symbol 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
We call % a wildcard because it matches any text with a length of zero or more symbols.

Make sure to pick %.

lessons.title: Zero or more symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
Matching zero or more symbols means that a pattern like 'a%' matches both 'Anne' and abbreviations like 'A'.

Make sure to pick %.

lessons.title: Match all values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since % matches any text of any length, we can match all items' first_name values using only '%' as a pattern.

Make sure to type '%'.

lessons.title: Question: No wildcard
lessons.interactiveContent:
What values does a pattern without a wildcard, like 'chocolate' here, match?

Only values that are equal to 'chocolate'Values that start, end with, or contain 'chocolate'

Only values that are equal to 'chocolate'.

lessons.title: Question: The % symbol 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we call the % symbol a wildcard?

Because it matches any text of zero or more charactersBecause it matches any text of at least five characters

Because it matches any text of zero or more characters.

lessons.title: Question: Zero or more symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the pattern in this condition match?

Values that start with 'chocolate'Values that are equal to 'chocolate'

Values that start with 'chocolate'.

lessons.title: Question: Match all values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which values will this pattern '%' match?

All of them, since the wildcard '%' matches any valueNone of them, since there's no value equal to '%'

All of them, since the wildcard '%' matches any value.

lessons.title: Example: No wildcard
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a pattern that doesn't match any of the aroma values.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by aroma and then LIKE, 'walnut'.

lessons.title: Example: The % symbol
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition so that the query selects items with an aroma value starting with 'walnut'.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by aroma and then LIKE, 'walnut%'.

lessons.title: Example: Zero or more symbols
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code aroma, followed by LIKE and the pattern 'c%', to match values starting with the letter c.

Make sure to type aroma LIKE 'c%'.

lessons.title: Example: Match all values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition that matches any aroma values, by using only the wildcard as a pattern '%'.

Make sure to type aroma LIKE '%'.

lessons.title: Placement matters
lessons.interactiveContent: Where we place the wildcard matters. Click on each button to see the difference between placing % at the beginning, end, or both.

lessons.title: Start with
lessons.interactiveContent:
To match values starting with a text like 'a', followed by any other text, we place the wildcard at the end like 'a%'.

Make sure to pick a, followed by %.

lessons.title: End with
lessons.interactiveContent:
To match values ending with a text like 'a', we place the wildcard at the beginning, like with '%a'.

Make sure to type '%a'.

lessons.title: Containing
lessons.interactiveContent:
To match values containing a text like 'a' in the beginning, end or middle, we use two wildcards, like '%a%'.

Make sure to type '%a%'.

lessons.title: Two wildcards
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using two wildcards, like with '%a%', we want to match any text of any length before and after the text 'a'.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by first_name and then LIKE, '%a%'.

lessons.title: Question: Placement matters
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why does the placement of the wildcard % in the pattern text matter?

Because depending on the placement, we could match a text that starts, ends with, or contains a patternIt doesn't matter

Because depending on the placement, we could match a text that starts, ends with, or contains a pattern.

lessons.title: Question: Start with
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which pattern matches values that start with the letter c?

'c%''%c'

Make sure to pick 'c%'.

lessons.title: Question: End with
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which pattern matches values that end with the letter c?

'%c''c%'

Make sure to pick '%c'.

lessons.title: Question: Containing
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which pattern matches values containing the letter c?

'%c%''c'

Make sure to pick '%c%'.

lessons.title: Question: Two wildcards
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which aroma value(s) will this pattern match?

'grape, white chocolate', since it contains 'white'No value, since none of them are equal to 'white'

'grape, white chocolate', since it contains 'white'.

lessons.title: Example: Placement matters
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select only items with name values containing the letter c doubled, like cc.

Make sure to pick ' followed by % and then cc, %, '.

lessons.title: Example: Start with
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a pattern to match values starting with 'chocolate'.

Make sure to pick ', followed by chocolate%, and finally '.

lessons.title: Example: End with
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a pattern that matches values ending in 'chocolate'.

Make sure to pick ' followed by % and then chocolate, '.

lessons.title: Example: Containing
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a pattern that matches values containing 'chocolate'.

Make sure to pick '%chocolate%'.

lessons.title: Example: Two wildcards
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use two wildcards, one before and one after the text, to code a pattern that matches values containing 'butter'.

Make sure to type '%butter%'.
